column2: The first time they see the Brachiosaurus is pure movie magic. I still get chills.
The raptors in the kitchen scene is the most terrifying sequence in any movie. Ever.
'Welcome to Jurassic Park.' Iconic line. Iconic movie.
'Clever girl.' Muldoon's last words before being outsmarted by the raptor are legendary.
The T-Rex roar is the greatest sound effect in film history. Period.
The T-Rex saving them from the raptors at the very end was the ultimate deus ex machina, and I loved it.
Dr. Ian Malcolm is the best character. Jeff Goldblum is a legend.
Nedry getting what he deserved from the Dilophosaurus was so satisfying.
The water cup vibrating to the T-Rex's footsteps is a masterclass in building tension.
The moment when Grant realizes the dinosaurs are breeding because of the frog DNA is a huge 'life finds a way' payoff.
This movie holds up so well. The CGI is still incredible for its time.
The lawyer getting eaten on the toilet is an all-time great movie death.
The sick Triceratops scene is such a wonderful, quiet moment in the middle of all the chaos.
The scene where the raptors are testing the fences... terrifying foreshadowing.
The music by John Williams is one of the most iconic scores ever written.
The reveal that they are all female to control the population, and how that fails, is a great part of the story.
The whole tour breaking down is when you know things are about to go very, very wrong.
Lex saving the day by getting the park's systems back online was a great hero moment for her.
'Life, uh, finds a way.' Best line in the movie.
The way the T-Rex eye dilates right next to the car window is pure nightmare fuel.
The Mr. DNA animation is so charmingly 90s.
The final shot of the pelicans is a perfect, subtle nod to the dinosaurs-to-birds theory.
The raptor tapping its claw on the ground is so menacing.
When the 'When Dinosaurs Ruled the Earth' banner falls at the end, it's a perfect symbolic shot.
The chemistry between Alan Grant and Ellie Sattler is so good.
The moment when the power goes out and the tour stops right in front of the T-Rex paddock is classic horror setup.
Tim is the most annoying and relatable kid character ever.
The escape from the T-Rex in the jeep is an all-time great action sequence.
The opening scene with the raptor transfer sets the tone perfectly. You know these things are dangerous.
The final showdown between the T-Rex and the raptors is a monster movie dream come true.
I love the ethical debates about whether they *should* have brought the dinosaurs back.
The reveal of the baby raptor hatching is both cute and terrifying.
The scene where Grant has to climb the electric fence with Tim is so tense.
The way the Dilophosaurus spits the venom is a great jump scare.
The helicopter ride to the island with that music is just perfect.
The fact that the T-Rex is essentially the anti-hero of the film by the end is brilliant.
The practical effects on the animatronic dinosaurs still look amazing.
The raptors figuring out how to open doors is the scariest part of the movie.
The film is just pure adventure and wonder.
The final scene of them in the helicopter, safe, feels so earned.
The science, even if it's a bit far-fetched, is explained so well.
The way Grant goes from hating kids to protecting them is a great character arc.
The scene where they are hiding from the T-Rex and it can't see them if they don't move is so iconic.
The reveal that frog DNA allowed them to change sex and breed is the key to the whole breakdown.
This movie made a whole generation of kids want to be paleontologists.
The way the raptors coordinate their hunt is so smart and scary.
The whole movie is a cautionary tale about playing God.
The reveal of the T-Rex at the end of the film to fight the raptors was a total surprise.
The score gives the whole movie a sense of wonder and grandeur.
The way they escape the kitchen is so clever.
It's the perfect blockbuster. Action, adventure, horror, and heart.
The final roar of the T-Rex as the banner falls is just cinematic perfection.
The characters are all so memorable and well-cast.
Nedry's greed is what causes the entire disaster. A classic trope done perfectly.
The brachiosaurus sneezing on Lex is a great funny moment.
The way the raptors are hyped up as the real threat before you even see them properly is great.
The movie is just pure magic. It still captures the imagination.
The T-Rex is the king for a reason. It saved the main characters.
The scene with the Gallimimus herd flocking is so beautiful.
The moment the raptor fogs up the window in the kitchen door... chills.
The perfect balance of awe and terror.
The fact that the T-Rex's final appearance is a total accident makes it even better.
The details in the park, like the jeeps and the visitor center, are so cool.
The raptors in the kitchen is peak horror. The tension is unbearable.
This movie will forever be a classic.
The T-Rex asserting its dominance at the end of the film is a legendary moment.
The way they established the rules of each dinosaur (vision based on movement, etc.) was great storytelling.
The moment they realize they're being hunted in the visitor center is so scary.
The film has a great sense of adventure that's missing in a lot of modern blockbusters.
The T-Rex is not a hero or a villain, just an animal, and that's why its final act is so cool.
The shot of the raptor's shadow on the wall is iconic.
The way the kitchen scene uses sound (or lack of it) is masterful.
Spielberg is the king of the blockbuster for a reason.
The moment the T-Rex breaks through the glass at the end is an all-time great movie moment.
The design of the visitor center is so cool and memorable.
The kitchen scene is still one of the most suspenseful scenes ever made.
The movie still feels as fresh and exciting as it did 30 years ago.
The final roar is the T-Rex reclaiming its throne as the king of the island.
Just a perfect adventure film.
The way the raptors work together to trap Muldoon is so smart.
The special effects were revolutionary and still look fantastic.
The T-Rex is the unexpected hero of the film's climax.
The way the kitchen scene plays out is a masterclass in suspense.
The movie is a timeless classic for a reason.
The final battle isn't between good and evil, it's just nature being nature.
The casting is perfect. Every actor fits their role perfectly.
The moment when the kids are saved by the T-Rex is a perfect surprise ending.
The film is an incredible achievement in filmmaking.
The kitchen scene is a masterclass in building and releasing tension.
The movie never gets old. It's a perfect adventure from start to finish.
The T-Rex becomes the unlikely savior, proving that life truly cannot be contained or predicted.
